title: 108_s2511
content: The Act may be cited as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004". It includes definitions related to the Chimayo Water Supply System. The Act, known as the "Chimayo Water Supply System and Espanola Filtration Facility Act of 2004," defines key terms such as Secretary, study area, system, and town related to the Chimayo Water Supply System feasibility study conducted by the Secretary of the Interior in the Santa Cruz River Valley. The study will determine the feasibility of constructing a water supply system for the Town, including transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs. Options for supplying water will be considered, such as connection to a regional water source, local sources, distributed sources throughout the Town, and sources on adjacent Bureau of Land Management land. The study will assess the feasibility of a water supply system for the Town, including transmission lines, pump stations, and storage reservoirs. Options like regional, local, distributed sources, and Bureau of Land Management land will be considered. The study must be completed within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will complete a study within 3 years, with a 75 percent Federal cost share. Coordination with various agencies will be required for accessing land and drilling exploratory wells to determine water resources for the Town. The Secretary will complete a study within 3 years to determine water resources for the Town. The Secretary may provide emergency water supply development assistance to eligible entities in the study area. The Secretary may provide assistance for activities such as hauling water, installing water purification technology, drilling wells, pump stations, storage reservoirs, pipelines, emergency water supply systems, and other eligible activities as determined appropriate. Cost sharing for activities is required. The Federal share of the cost for activities under this section is 75 percent. SEC. 104 authorizes appropriations for sections 102 and 103 for fiscal years 2005-2008 and 2005-2010 respectively. Funds under subsection (a)(1) cannot be used for water infrastructure construction. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of the Espanola water filtration facility in New Mexico, which includes projects to divert and utilize imported water. The terms "component," "facility," and "Secretary" are defined in relation to the water delivery infrastructure development. The Secretary will provide financial assistance for the construction of water infrastructure in Espanola, New Mexico, including presedimentation basins, pump stations, treatment facilities, filtration facilities, storage facilities, booster pump station, sludge dewatering facilities, and water transmission lines. The Secretary may provide financial assistance for the study, planning, design, and construction of water delivery infrastructure for the Santa Clara and San Juan Pueblos in New Mexico, with a Federal share not exceeding 25 percent of the total cost. Funds provided by the Secretary cannot be used for the operation or maintenance of the facility or component. Authorization of $3,000,000 for facility construction from 2005 to 2009.
